title: Bank of China contributes to USD 500 million syndicated loan to Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas for refinancing purposes (Linked to Project ID#98410)
description: In February 2003, a syndicate of twelve banks entered into a USD 500 million loan to Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas for refinancing purposes. The original arrangers included Citibank/SSB (Citigroup), Crédit Lyonnais, HSBC, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (SMBC), Tokyo-Mitsubishi International, and Mizuho Bank. Sub-writers included LBKiel, Bank of China, Land Bank of the Philippines. Metrobank, and KBC Bank. As of February 28, 2003, the loan was set to be launched into general syndication with responses due in mid-March.  Borrowing terms included a maturity period of five years and an interest rate of LIBOR plus 233 basis points.   This loan was meant to refinance a USD 500 million three-year term loan that was arranged by ABN Amro and completed in April 2000. It is unknown whether Chinese financing occurred in the original loan.   ICBC's contribution is captured in Project ID#98410 and Bank of China's contribution is captured in Project ID#98411
staff_comments: 1. Since the individual contributions of the twelve known syndicate members are unknown, AidData assumes each lender contributed an equal amount (USD 41,666,666).2. AidData has estimated the interest rate by adding 2.33% to the average six-month LIBOR in February 2003 (1.343%).
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
Bank of China contributes to USD 500 million syndicated loan to Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas for refinancing purposes (Linked to Project ID#98410)

# Description
In February 2003, a syndicate of twelve banks entered into a USD 500 million loan to Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas for refinancing purposes. The original arrangers included Citibank/SSB (Citigroup), Crédit Lyonnais, HSBC, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (SMBC), Tokyo-Mitsubishi International, and Mizuho Bank. Sub-writers included LBKiel, Bank of China, Land Bank of the Philippines. Metrobank, and KBC Bank. As of February 28, 2003, the loan was set to be launched into general syndication with responses due in mid-March.  Borrowing terms included a maturity period of five years and an interest rate of LIBOR plus 233 basis points.   This loan was meant to refinance a USD 500 million three-year term loan that was arranged by ABN Amro and completed in April 2000. It is unknown whether Chinese financing occurred in the original loan.   ICBC's contribution is captured in Project ID#98410 and Bank of China's contribution is captured in Project ID#98411
justification: Project involves financial services for refinancing purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Syndicated loan for refinancing purposes, no specific environmental or energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides $5.4m buyer's credit loan to Vneshtorgbank for the purchase of Huawei Equipment (linked to #40503)
description: In September 2003, China's Eximbank granted Russia's Vneshtorgbank a $5.4 million USD buyer's credit loan for four years to finance Huawei equipment supply for Uralsvyazinform. The loan was provided under the basic export buyer's credit agreement between Russia's Vneshtorgbank and China's Eximbank to the sum of $100 million USD for up to 10 years signed in December 2002 for financing credits to Russian importers (see linked ProjectID#40503). The deal is insured by Sinosure export insurance agency. Under the credit line, Uralsvyazinform has already received equipment for telephone lines in Perm and equipment for a GSM-network in Yamalo-Nenetskii autonomous region.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides $5.4m buyer's credit loan to Vneshtorgbank for the purchase of Huawei Equipment (linked to #40503)

The loan was provided under the basic export buyer's credit agreement between Russia's Vneshtorgbank and China's Eximbank to the sum of $100 million USD for up to 10 years signed in December 2002 for financing credits to Russian importers (see linked ProjectID#40503). The deal is insured by Sinosure export insurance agency. Under the credit line, Uralsvyazinform has already received equipment for telephone lines in Perm and equipment for a GSM-network in Yamalo-Nenetskii autonomous region.
justification: Project involves financing for communications equipment with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Purchase of Huawei equipment for telephone lines and GSM network, communications sector focus

title: China Construction Bank provides $200 million loan to VTB Bank for on-lending purposes
description: On May 27, 2003, Vneshtorgbank (VTB Bank) and China Construction Bank (CCB) signed a $200 million, 10-year credit (loan) agreement for on-lending purposes. The agreement was signed by Mr. Andrey Kostin, President and C.E.O., for Vneshtorgbank, and Mr. Enzhao Zhang, President, for China Construction Bank. The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds to finance the export of Chinese durable goods to Russia. Sinosure provided credit insurance to the borrower.
staff_comments: 1. VTB Bank is a Russian majority state-owned bank headquartered in various federal districts of Russia; its legal address is registered in St. Petersburg; as of 2022 company's capital stock was mostly owned by three Russian agencies.2. Prior to the signed of the agreement with CCB, VTB Bank had previously signed similar agreements with the other three largest banks of China.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
China Construction Bank provides $200 million loan to VTB Bank for on-lending purposes

# Description
On May 27, 2003, Vneshtorgbank (VTB Bank) and China Construction Bank (CCB) signed a $200 million, 10-year credit (loan) agreement for on-lending purposes. The agreement was signed by Mr. Andrey Kostin, President and C.E.O., for Vneshtorgbank, and Mr. Enzhao Zhang, President, for China Construction Bank. The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds to finance the export of Chinese durable goods to Russia. Sinosure provided credit insurance to the borrower.
justification: Project involves financial services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Loan agreement between banks for on-lending purposes, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: ICBC, through VTB, provides buyer's credit loan facility worth $7.4 million to finance the purchase of Huawei products for MegaFon
description: In August 2003, ICBC, VTB, and Megafon signed an export buyer's credit loan agreement for two loan facilities worth USD $4.1 and $3.3 million for Megafon to purchase Huawei telecom products for the Khabarovsk and Novosibirsk subsidiaries of Megafon. The length of the facility is 6 years. The loan facility is insured by Sinosure. The money is coming from ICBC to VTB, which is in turn disbursing it to Megafon.   Because of this deal, Megafon became the first telecommunications company in Russia to use Huawei equipment. This agreement is a part of the greater modernization effort by Megafon, where the supply of equipment from Huawei will be done in several stages.   According to the Megafon annual report, " Vneshtorgbank acted as the Russian bank that transferred a loan from the Industry and Commerce Bank of China to MegaFon".
combined_text:
# Sector

The length of the facility is 6 years. The loan facility is insured by Sinosure. The money is coming from ICBC to VTB, which is in turn disbursing it to Megafon.   Because of this deal, Megafon became the first telecommunications company in Russia to use Huawei equipment. This agreement is a part of the greater modernization effort by Megafon, where the supply of equipment from Huawei will be done in several stages.   According to the Megafon annual report, " Vneshtorgbank acted as the Russian bank that transferred a loan from the Industry and Commerce Bank of China to MegaFon".
justification: Project involves financing telecom equipment purchases, which does not have direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Loan facility for purchase of Huawei telecom products, telecommunications sector focus

title: Bank of China signs $100 million credit facility with Gazprombank to finance Chinese exports
description: In March 2003, Bank of China signed a $100 million credit facility agreement with Gazprombank to finance the purchase of Chinese goods. The facility has a maturity of 5 years and an interest rate of LIBOR plus a 3% margin.
staff_comments: 1.  A Gazprombank source states that 'the annual rate does not exceed LIBOR + 3%.' Given that average 6 month LIBOR in March 2003 was 1.264%, the all-n interest rate has been estimated as 1.264% + 3% = 4.264%.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
Bank of China signs $100 million credit facility with Gazprombank to finance Chinese exports

# Description
In March 2003, Bank of China signed a $100 million credit facility agreement with Gazprombank to finance the purchase of Chinese goods. The facility has a maturity of 5 years and an interest rate of LIBOR plus a 3% margin.
justification: Project is a financial credit facility without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Credit facility for financing Chinese exports, no specific energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Amahoro National Stadium Renovation Project
description: In 2003, the Chinese Government committed to provide a grant to the Government of Rwanda (through an exchange of notes) to renovate Amahoro National Stadium. The stadium is located in eastern Kigali in Gasabo district near the capital’s international airport. This project involved renovation of the sports facilities, lighting, sound system, and sanitation systems.  It also involved the installation of 4,950 seats in the VIP area, the installation of an electronic scoreboard, and the addition of a basketball and volleyball court. Project implementation began on December 20, 2004. It was completed on November 19, 2005. The project was implemented by China Beijing International Economic Cooperation Corporation.
staff_comments: The Chinese name of this project is 卢旺达国家体育场维修工程 or 卢旺达和平体育场. The original construction of the Amahoro stadium was funded by the Chinese and Government and implemented by China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation. The project was initiated in 1984 and completed in 1988. It cost $42 million to build.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Amahoro National Stadium Renovation Project

# Description
In 2003, the Chinese Government committed to provide a grant to the Government of Rwanda (through an exchange of notes) to renovate Amahoro National Stadium. The stadium is located in eastern Kigali in Gasabo district near the capital’s international airport. This project involved renovation of the sports facilities, lighting, sound system, and sanitation systems.  It also involved the installation of 4,950 seats in the VIP area, the installation of an electronic scoreboard, and the addition of a basketball and volleyball court. Project implementation began on December 20, 2004. It was completed on November 19, 2005. The project was implemented by China Beijing International Economic Cooperation Corporation.
justification: Project focuses on sports facility renovation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Renovation of sports facilities, lighting, sound system, sanitation systems, and addition of basketball/volleyball courts

title: China donated a Satellite Dish and receiver to St. Lucia's Department of Information Services
description: On July 14, 2003, the Chinese government granted a satellite dish and receiver to the Department of Information Services for the National Television Network. The dish would allow the St. Lucian people to access Chinese channels. This project was aimed at promoting cultural exchange between China and St. Lucia, falling under "representational" intent. The value of the dish is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China donated a Satellite Dish and receiver to St. Lucia's Department of Information Services

# Description
On July 14, 2003, the Chinese government granted a satellite dish and receiver to the Department of Information Services for the National Television Network. The dish would allow the St. Lucian people to access Chinese channels. This project was aimed at promoting cultural exchange between China and St. Lucia, falling under "representational" intent. The value of the dish is unknown.
justification: Project is focused on communications infrastructure for cultural exchange, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Satellite dish and receiver for television network, cultural exchange purpose

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 68 million grant — via ETCA — for Aquatic Center Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#72229)
description: On September 4, 2003, the Chinese Government and Samoan Government signed an exchange of letters, which committed grant funding for the Aquatic Center Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) committed RMB 68 million of grant funding in total. The grant proceeds were drawn in part from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on October 9, 2003 (captured via Project ID#72229).   The purpose of this project was to construct an aquatic center with an 8,869 square meter pool in the Tuanaimato area of the city of Apia. Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Corporation was the contractor responsible for implementation. It signed a construction contract on October 9, 2004. A groundbreaking ceremony — attended by Prime Minister Tuilaepa and Chinese Ambassador Liu Guanren — took place on December 11, 2004. Construction ended in December 2005 and the aquatic center was officially inaugurated on January 16, 2006. The Miss South Pacific Pageant was held at the Samoa Aquatic Center on November 10, 2006. The facility was also used during the 2007 South Pacific Games, which were held in Apia from August 25, 2007 to September 8, 2007.   According to the Lowy Institute and several media reports, this project has been controversial because the Government of Samoa was unable to finance the recurring costs of maintaining the swimming pool at the Aquatic Center and it asked the Government of New Zealand to shoulder this expense.
staff_comments: Staff Note: This project is also known as the Samoan Swimming Pool Project and the Samoa Aquatic Centre (SAC) Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 萨摩亚游泳馆项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title

# Description
On September 4, 2003, the Chinese Government and Samoan Government signed an exchange of letters, which committed grant funding for the Aquatic Center Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) committed RMB 68 million of grant funding in total. The grant proceeds were drawn in part from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on October 9, 2003 (captured via Project ID#72229).   The purpose of this project was to construct an aquatic center with an 8,869 square meter pool in the Tuanaimato area of the city of Apia. Anhui Foreign Economic Construction Corporation was the contractor responsible for implementation. It signed a construction contract on October 9, 2004. A groundbreaking ceremony — attended by Prime Minister Tuilaepa and Chinese Ambassador Liu Guanren — took place on December 11, 2004. Construction ended in December 2005 and the aquatic center was officially inaugurated on January 16, 2006. The Miss South Pacific Pageant was held at the Samoa Aquatic Center on November 10, 2006. The facility was also used during the 2007 South Pacific Games, which were held in Apia from August 25, 2007 to September 8, 2007.   According to the Lowy Institute and several media reports, this project has been controversial because the Government of Samoa was unable to finance the recurring costs of maintaining the swimming pool at the Aquatic Center and it asked the Government of New Zealand to shoulder this expense.
justification: Project is focused on social infrastructure development with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of aquatic center for community use, primarily for social and recreational purposes

title: Sinochem forgives $70 million of debt owed by Serbian state-owned oil and gas company
description: In 2003, Sinochem International Oil Company — a Chinese state-owned oil trading company that operates under the supervision of the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC) — sued Serbia’s state-owned oil and gas company, Naftna Industrija Srbije (NIS), after it failed to settle an approximately $268 million bill for crude oil deliveries. The debt resulted from an agreement during the 1990s in which Sinochem delivered 14.6 million barrels of crude oil  to NIS between 1991 and 1998. Sinochem halted its oil exports in 1998 when its NIS could no longer fulfill its payment obligations. NIS claimed that it did not have the funds to repay its debts, which it had inherited from the former Milosevic government.   Then, on November 7, 2003, Sinochem and NIS signed a debt relief protocol agreement. Under the terms of this agreement, Sinochem reportedly exempted NIS from $70 million worth of repayment obligations. Then, under the terms of a deal (‘deed of agreement’) that was finalized on October 11, 2004, the parties agreed that remaining repayment obligations of NIS (worth approximately $196 million as of 2004) would be repayable in sixteen, semi-annual installments of approximately $14.2 million over an eight year period (from June 30, 2004 to December 31, 2011). The interest rate on these outstanding obligations were reduced from 4.4% to LIBOR plus a 0.7% margin. The 6 month average LIBOR rate in October 2004 was 2.227%, so AidData codes the all-in interest rate as 2.227% + 0.7% = 2.927%. This debt rescheduling agreement was signed during an official visit of Serbia’s prime minister Zoran Zivkovic to China. NIS made its first repayment of $14.2 million on June 30, 2004. Project ID#42320 captures the debt forgiveness that was granted to NIS and Project ID#67011 captures the rescheduling of the outstanding obligations of NIS.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Sinochem forgives $70 million of debt owed by Serbian state-owned oil and gas company

# Description
In 2003, Sinochem International Oil Company — a Chinese state-owned oil trading company that operates under the supervision of the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC) — sued Serbia’s state-owned oil and gas company, Naftna Industrija Srbije (NIS), after it failed to settle an approximately $268 million bill for crude oil deliveries. The debt resulted from an agreement during the 1990s in which Sinochem delivered 14.6 million barrels of crude oil  to NIS between 1991 and 1998. Sinochem halted its oil exports in 1998 when its NIS could no longer fulfill its payment obligations. NIS claimed that it did not have the funds to repay its debts, which it had inherited from the former Milosevic government.   Then, on November 7, 2003, Sinochem and NIS signed a debt relief protocol agreement. Under the terms of this agreement, Sinochem reportedly exempted NIS from $70 million worth of repayment obligations. Then, under the terms of a deal (‘deed of agreement’) that was finalized on October 11, 2004, the parties agreed that remaining repayment obligations of NIS (worth approximately $196 million as of 2004) would be repayable in sixteen, semi-annual installments of approximately $14.2 million over an eight year period (from June 30, 2004 to December 31, 2011). The interest rate on these outstanding obligations were reduced from 4.4% to LIBOR plus a 0.7% margin. The 6 month average LIBOR rate in October 2004 was 2.227%, so AidData codes the all-in interest rate as 2.227% + 0.7% = 2.927%. This debt rescheduling agreement was signed during an official visit of Serbia’s prime minister Zoran Zivkovic to China. NIS made its first repayment of $14.2 million on June 30, 2004. Project ID#42320 captures the debt forgiveness that was granted to NIS and Project ID#67011 captures the rescheduling of the outstanding obligations of NIS.
justification: Project involves debt forgiveness and restructuring of financial obligations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt forgiveness agreement, financial restructuring terms, no direct project implementation or infrastructure development
